In biochemistry, 'PMSF' (phenylmethanesulfonylfluoride or phenylmethylsulfonyl
fluoride) is a serine protease inhibitor commonly used in the preparation of
cell lysates. PMSF does not inhibit all serine proteases. It is rapidly degraded
in water and stock solutions are usually made up in anhydrous ethanol,
isopropanol, corn oil, or DMSO. Proteolytic inhibition occurs when a
concentration between 0.1 - 1 mM PMSF is used. The half-life is short in aqueous
solutions (110 min at pH 7, 55 min at pH 7.5, and 35 min at pH 8, all at
25Â°C).

PMSF binds specifically to the active site serine residue in a serine protease.
It does not bind to any other serine residues in the protein. This is a result
of the hyperactivity of that serine residue caused by the specific environmental
conditions in the enzyme's active site. Because PMSF binds covalently to the
enzyme, the complex can be viewed by X-ray crystallography; it can therefore be
used as a chemical label to identify an essential active site SER in an enzyme.

PMSF is commonly used in protein solublization in order to deactivate proteases
from digesting proteins of interest after cell lysis.
